elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of novel covalent organic−inorganic architectures containing organically functionalized supertetrahedra is described. The structures of these unique materials consist of one-dimensional zigzag chains or of honeycomb-type layers, in which gallium−sulfide supertetrahedral clusters and dipyridyl ligands alternate.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis and characterization of novel covalent organic-inorganic architectures containing organically functionalized supertetrahedra is described. The structures of these unique materials consist of one-dimensional zigzag chains or of honeycomb-type layers, in which gallium-sulfide supertetrahedral clusters and dipyridyl ligands alternate.

elements.content: In recent years a significant progress has been made in the synthesis of inorganic open-frameworks built from supertetrahedral clusters, which can be described as tetrahedrally shaped fragments of the ZnS structure. However, only a small number of three-dimensional topologies, such as CrB4 or C3N4, have been found, with the single- and double-diamond lattice being by far the most common. This paucity of topological types has been attributed to the lack of flexibility of the metal−sulfur−metal angle, which limits the ways in which tetrahedral clusters can be joined together. To obtain new three-dimensional structural types, it is necessary to devise alternative ways of linking the clusters. A route that offers enormous potential is the incorporation of organic moieties as linkers between clusters, as this would result in the generation of novel organic−inorganic architectures. A small number of reports on metal−thiolate cluster superlattices demonstrate the feasibility of this approach which, to the best of our knowledge, has never been applied to metal−chalcogenide tetrahedral clusters.
elements.clean_text: In recent years a significant progress has been made in the synthesis of inorganic open-frameworks built from supertetrahedral clusters, which can be described as tetrahedrally shaped fragments of the ZnS structure. However, only a small number of three-dimensional topologies, such as CrB4  or C3N4, have been found, with the single- and double-diamond lattice being by far the most common. This paucity of topological types has been attributed to the lack of flexibility of the metal-sulfur-metal angle, which limits the ways in which tetrahedral clusters can be joined together. To obtain new three-dimensional structural types, it is necessary to devise alternative ways of linking the clusters. A route that offers enormous potential is the incorporation of organic moieties as linkers between clusters, as this would result in the generation of novel organic-inorganic architectures. A small number of reports on metal-thiolate cluster superlattices demonstrate the feasibility of this approach which, to the best of our knowledge, has never been applied to metal-chalcogenide tetrahedral clusters.

elements.content: Following our recent report of an unprecedented supertetrahedral cluster, [Ga10S16(NC7H9)4]2−, in which the gallium atoms at the corners of the cluster exhibit a tetrahedral environment through additional coordination to organic amines, we describe here our initial results on the synthesis and characterization of novel covalent organic−inorganic architectures containing organically functionalized supertetrahedra. These unique materials, in which bidentate ligands act as linkers between gallium−sulfide supertetrahedral clusters, can be described as a new type of metal−organic framework. Such hybrid materials may possess unique optical and photochemical properties due to the interaction at the microscopic level between the organic and the inorganic components.
elements.clean_text: Following our recent report of an unprecedented supertetrahedral cluster, [Ga10S16(NC7H9)4]2-, in which the gallium atoms at the corners of the cluster exhibit a tetrahedral environment through additional coordination to organic amines, we describe here our initial results on the synthesis and characterization of novel covalent organic-inorganic architectures containing organically functionalized supertetrahedra. These unique materials, in which bidentate ligands act as linkers between gallium-sulfide supertetrahedral clusters, can be described as a new type of metal-organic framework. Such hybrid materials may possess unique optical and photochemical properties due to the interaction at the microscopic level between the organic and the inorganic components.

elements.content: By using 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (DPE) as a linker between gallium−sulfide supertetrahedral clusters, we have succeeded in the synthesis of one- and two-dimensional covalent organic−inorganic networks. The building units of these materials are supertetrahedral clusters in which the sulfur atoms at the vertexes have been replaced by a combination of mono- and bidentate pyridine derivatives. These clusters are closely related to the series of supertetrahedral Tn clusters, where n refers to the number of individual tetrahedra along the edge of the cluster, with the materials reported here containing T3-type clusters. In these clusters, all gallium atoms exhibit tetrahedral coordination, whereas the sulfur atoms located on the faces of the supertetrahedron are trigonally coordinated and the remaining sulfur atoms are bicoordinated. In the structures reported here, the Ga−N distances take average values of 2.03−2.06 Å, which are significantly shorter than the Ga−S distances (ca. 2.27 Å), and similar to that found for the isolated [Ga10S16(NC7H9)4]2− cluster (2.045(5) Å).
elements.clean_text: By using 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (DPE) as a linker between gallium-sulfide supertetrahedral clusters, we have succeeded in the synthesis of one- and two-dimensional covalent organic-inorganic networks. The building units of these materials are supertetrahedral clusters in which the sulfur atoms at the vertexes have been replaced by a combination of mono- and bidentate pyridine derivatives. These clusters are closely related to the series of supertetrahedral Tn clusters, where n refers to the number of individual tetrahedra along the edge of the cluster, with the materials reported here containing T3-type clusters. In these clusters, all gallium atoms exhibit tetrahedral coordination, whereas the sulfur atoms located on the faces of the supertetrahedron are trigonally coordinated and the remaining sulfur atoms are bicoordinated. In the structures reported here, the Ga-N distances take average values of 2.03-2.06 Å, which are significantly shorter than the Ga-S distances (ca. 2.27 Å), and similar to that found for the isolated [Ga10S16(NC7H9)4]2- cluster (2.045(5) Å).

elements.content: The structure of [C6H8N]2[Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)] (1) contains one-dimensional zigzag chains of alternating T3-type clusters and dipyridyl ligands (Figure a). The two remaining vertexes of the supertetrahedral clusters are terminated by monodentate 4-methylpyridine molecules. Under the reducing solvothermal conditions in which this reaction has taken place, hydrogenation of DPE has resulted in the formation of 1,2,-di(4-pyridyl)ethane, which is capable of adopting the conformation shown in Figure a. The zigzag hybrid chains are packed in layers parallel to the (010) plane (Figure b), with the 4-methylpyridine ligands oriented toward the outer part of the layers (Figure c). Given that the [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2− chains are anionic, and that the determined crystal structure contains ca. 39% of void space, protonated amine cations are assumed to be located within the crystal structure cavities. Elemental analysis is consistent with the incorporation of two 4-methylpyridinium cations per formula unit. Using pyridine as a solvent, an isostructural material, with stoichiometry [C5H6N]2[Ga10S16(NC5H5)2(N2C12H12)], can be prepared.
elements.clean_text: The structure of [C6H8N]2[Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)] (1) contains one-dimensional zigzag chains of alternating T3-type clusters and dipyridyl ligands (Figure a). The two remaining vertexes of the supertetrahedral clusters are terminated by monodentate 4-methylpyridine molecules. Under the reducing solvothermal conditions in which this reaction has taken place, hydrogenation of DPE has resulted in the formation of 1,2,-di(4-pyridyl)ethane, which is capable of adopting the conformation shown in Figure a. The zigzag hybrid chains are packed in layers parallel to the (010) plane (Figure b), with the 4-methylpyridine ligands oriented toward the outer part of the layers (Figure c). Given that the [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2- chains are anionic, and that the determined crystal structure contains ca. 39% of void space, protonated amine cations are assumed to be located within the crystal structure cavities. Elemental analysis is consistent with the incorporation of two 4-methylpyridinium cations per formula unit. Using pyridine as a solvent, an isostructural material, with stoichiometry [C5H6N]2[Ga10S16(NC5H5)2(N2C12H12)], can be prepared.

elements.content: (a) A one-dimensional [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2− chain; (b) schematic representation of a layer of 1 parallel to (010) showing the arrangement of the zigzag chains; (c) view of 1 along [001].
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) A one-dimensional [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2- chain; (b) schematic representation of a layer of 1 parallel to (010) showing the arrangement of the zigzag chains; (c) view of 1 along [001].

elements.content: The structure of [C7H10N]2[Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2] (2) contains T3-type supertetrahedral clusters in which three of the terminal S2− anions have been replaced by DPE, while the remaining vertex is terminated by a 3,5-dimethylpyridine molecule. The bidentate DPE molecules act as linkers between the supertetrahedral clusters, resulting in the formation of covalent organic−inorganic layers with a honeycomb-type topology (Figure a). These corrugated layers, which have a pore diameter of ca. 30 Å, are stacked parallel to the (135) plane. The staggered arrangement of the layers within the crystal structure resembles that of gray arsenic (Figure b), and leads to the partial filling of the pores in a given layer by supertetrahedra from neighboring layers. However, the crystal structure of 2 still contains ca. 38% of solvent accessible void space, and a two-dimensional network of channels of approximately 3−4 Å diameter, running parallel to the b- and a-axes, is apparent in space-filling representations of this structure. Given the anionic nature of the hybrid layers, these channels are likely to be filled with protonated amine cations. Elemental analysis results are reasonably consistent with the presence of two protonated 3,5,-dimethylpyridinium cations per formula unit. The topology of 2 can be considered to be related to that of the wholly inorganic compound [Ba3(H2O)16][Mn6(H2O)3(μ6-Se)(GeSe4)4], which consists of [Mn6Ge4Se17]6− building units linked into honeycomb-like layers.
elements.clean_text: The structure of [C7H10N]2[Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2] (2) contains T3-type supertetrahedral clusters in which three of the terminal S2- anions have been replaced by DPE, while the remaining vertex is terminated by a 3,5-dimethylpyridine molecule. The bidentate DPE molecules act as linkers between the supertetrahedral clusters, resulting in the formation of covalent organic-inorganic layers with a honeycomb-type topology (Figure a). These corrugated layers, which have a pore diameter of ca. 30 Å, are stacked parallel to the (135) plane. The staggered arrangement of the layers within the crystal structure resembles that of gray arsenic (Figure b), and leads to the partial filling of the pores in a given layer by supertetrahedra from neighboring layers. However, the crystal structure of 2 still contains ca. 38% of solvent accessible void space, and a two-dimensional network of channels of approximately 3-4 Å diameter, running parallel to the b- and a-axes, is apparent in space-filling representations of this structure. Given the anionic nature of the hybrid layers, these channels are likely to be filled with protonated amine cations. Elemental analysis results are reasonably consistent with the presence of two protonated 3,5,-dimethylpyridinium cations per formula unit. The topology of 2 can be considered to be related to that of the wholly inorganic compound [Ba3(H2O)16][Mn6(H2O)3(μ6-Se)(GeSe4)4], which consists of [Mn6Ge4Se17]6- building units linked into honeycomb-like layers.

elements.content: (a) View of a two-dimensional [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2− layer parallel to the (135) plane; (b) framework topology of 2, each node represents a supertetrahedral cluster; (c) view of 2 along [100].
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of a two-dimensional [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2- layer parallel to the (135) plane; (b) framework topology of 2, each node represents a supertetrahedral cluster; (c) view of 2 along [100].

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that, under a N2 atmosphere, 1 and 2 are stable up to ca. 270 and 370 °C, respectively. Both phases are insoluble in common solvents, such as water, DMF, or THF. The optical behavior of these covalent organic−inorganic phases is comparable to that previously reported for wholly inorganic gallium−sulfide frameworks. From the optical absorption spectra band gaps of 3.3 and 3.7 eV were estimated for 1 and 2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that, under a N2 atmosphere, 1 and 2 are stable up to ca. 270 and 370 °C, respectively. Both phases are insoluble in common solvents, such as water, DMF, or THF. The optical behavior of these covalent organic-inorganic phases is comparable to that previously reported for wholly inorganic gallium-sulfide frameworks. From the optical absorption spectra band gaps of 3.3 and 3.7 eV were estimated for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have established that dipyridyl ligands can be used as linkers between supertetrahedral clusters to generate novel organic−inorganic networks. We anticipate that the materials reported here are the first representatives of a large family of hybrid supertetrahedra-based materials. Our synthetic efforts to date indicate that, in the gallium-sulfide system, organically functionalized supertetrahedra are a prevalent building block, found under a variety of solvothermal conditions. While we have demonstrated the feasibility of the synthesis of supertetrahedra-based networks using ditopic ligands, we envisage that multitopic linkers will enable the design of covalent organic−inorganic architectures with a wide range of connectivities, in which both the composition and the structure of the clusters and the organic ligands can be tuned to optimize desirable properties.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have established that dipyridyl ligands can be used as linkers between supertetrahedral clusters to generate novel organic-inorganic networks. We anticipate that the materials reported here are the first representatives of a large family of hybrid supertetrahedra-based materials. Our synthetic efforts to date indicate that, in the gallium-sulfide system, organically functionalized supertetrahedra are a prevalent building block, found under a variety of solvothermal conditions. While we have demonstrated the feasibility of the synthesis of supertetrahedra-based networks using ditopic ligands, we envisage that multitopic linkers will enable the design of covalent organic-inorganic architectures with a wide range of connectivities, in which both the composition and the structure of the clusters and the organic ligands can be tuned to optimize desirable properties.

elements.content: Space filling views of the structure of 2, crystallographic data in CIF format, observed and simulated powder X-ray diffraction data, and UV−vis diffuse reflectance, FT-IR, and TGA data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Space filling views of the structure of 2, crystallographic data in CIF format, observed and simulated powder X-ray diffraction data, and UV-vis diffuse reflectance, FT-IR, and TGA data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared by mixing gallium metal (Alfa Aesar 99.99%, 139 mg), sulfur (Alfa Aesar 99.5%, 144 mg), DPE (Fluka ≥98%, 182 mg) and 4-methylpyridine (Aldrich 98%, 3 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 170 °C for 5 days and then allowed to cool to room temperature at 1 °C min−1. For the synthesis of 2, 3,5-dimethylpyridine (Aldrich, 98+%) was used as a solvent, and crystals were produced by heating a mixture with an approximate molar composition Ga:S:DPE:3,5-dimethylpyridine, 2:4.5:1:26, at 200 °C for 20 days. Anal. Calcd for 1 (%): C, 24.44; H, 2.39; N, 4.75. Found: C, 23.92; H, 2.91; N, 5.36. Anal Calcd for 2 (%): C, 25.92; H, 2.45; N, 4.65. Found: C, 25.70; H, 2.87; N, 5.86
elements.clean_text:
References

Compound 1 was prepared by mixing gallium metal (Alfa Aesar 99.99%, 139 mg), sulfur (Alfa Aesar 99.5%, 144 mg), DPE (Fluka ≥98%, 182 mg) and 4-methylpyridine (Aldrich 98%, 3 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The vessel was sealed and heated at 170 °C for 5 days and then allowed to cool to room temperature at 1 °C min-1. For the synthesis of 2, 3,5-dimethylpyridine (Aldrich, 98+%) was used as a solvent, and crystals were produced by heating a mixture with an approximate molar composition Ga:S:DPE:3,5-dimethylpyridine, 2:4.5:1:26, at 200 °C for 20 days. Anal. Calcd for 1 (%): C, 24.44; H, 2.39; N, 4.75. Found: C, 23.92; H, 2.91; N, 5.36. Anal Calcd for 2 (%): C, 25.92; H, 2.45; N, 4.65. Found: C, 25.70; H, 2.87; N, 5.86

elements.content: Crystal structures: (a) [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2− (1), M = 1580.75, orthorhombic, space group Pcca, a = 37.4329(14) Å, b = 19.7762(8) Å, c = 18.5622(7) Å, V = 13741.2(9) Å3, Z = 8. Crystal dimensions: 0.28 × 0.24 × 0.1 mm3; 156171 reflections measured, 20783 unique (R merg = 0.0513, 6921 observed with I > 2σ(I)) which were used in all calculations. Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0424 and 0.0448, respectively. (b) [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2− (2), M = 1590.75, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 12.4678(12) Å, b = 13.6806(13) Å, c = 20.385(2) Å, α = 81.599(6)°, β = 88.542(5)°, γ = 82.967(5)° V = 3413.8(6) Å3, Z = 2. Crystal dimensions: 0.7 × 0.36 × 0.16 mm3; 89986 reflections measured, 20798 unique (R merg = 0.0336, 11508 observed with I > 2σ(I)) which were used in all calculations). Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0636 and 0.0788, respectively. Data collected using a Bruker X2 APEX 2 diffractometer (Mo Kα λ = 0.71073 Å), at 100 K. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SIR92 and model refined using CRYSTALS. The C and N atoms of the amine molecules were modeled isotropically. In 2 some of the dipyridyl ligands were found to be disordered over two crystallographically inequivalent positions, and therefore their site occupancies refined. The data were treated with SQUEEZE to correct the effect of the disordered organic cations

Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0424 and 0.0448, respectively. (b) [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2- (2), M  = 1590.75, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 12.4678(12) Å, b = 13.6806(13) Å, c = 20.385(2) Å, α = 81.599(6)°, β = 88.542(5)°, γ = 82.967(5)° V = 3413.8(6) Å3, Z = 2. Crystal dimensions: 0.7 × 0.36 × 0.16 mm3; 89986 reflections measured, 20798 unique (R merg = 0.0336, 11508 observed with I > 2σ(I)) which were used in all calculations). Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0636 and 0.0788, respectively. Data collected using a Bruker X2 APEX 2 diffractometer (Mo Kα λ = 0.71073 Å), at 100 K. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SIR92 and model refined using CRYSTALS. The C and N atoms of the amine molecules were modeled isotropically. In 2 some of the dipyridyl ligands were found to be disordered over two crystallographically inequivalent positions, and therefore their site occupancies refined. cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis indicates that, under a N2 atmosphere, 1 and 2 are stable up to ca. 270 and 370 °C, respectively. Both phases are insoluble in common solvents, such as water, DMF, or THF. The optical behavior of these covalent organic−inorganic phases is comparable to that previously reported for wholly inorganic gallium−sulfide frameworks. From the optical absorption spectra band gaps of 3.3 and 3.7 eV were estimated for 1 and 2, respectively.

Crystal structures: (a) [Ga10S16(NC6H7)2(N2C12H12)]2− (1), M = 1580.75, orthorhombic, space group Pcca, a = 37.4329(14) Å, b = 19.7762(8) Å, c = 18.5622(7) Å, V = 13741.2(9) Å3, Z = 8. Crystal dimensions: 0.28 × 0.24 × 0.1 mm3; 156171 reflections measured, 20783 unique (R merg = 0.0513, 6921 observed with I > 2σ(I)) which were used in all calculations. Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0424 and 0.0448, respectively. (b) [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2− (2), M = 1590.75, triclinic, space group P1̅, a = 12.4678(12) Å, b = 13.6806(13) Å, c = 20.385(2) Å, α = 81.599(6)°, β = 88.542(5)°, γ = 82.967(5)° V = 3413.8(6) Å3, Z = 2. Crystal dimensions: 0.7 × 0.36 × 0.16 mm3; 89986 reflections measured, 20798 unique (R merg = 0.0336, 11508 observed with I > 2σ(I)) which were used in all calculations). Final values of R(F) and wR(F) were 0.0636 and 0.0788, respectively. Data collected using a Bruker X2 APEX 2 diffractometer (Mo Kα λ = 0.71073 Å), at 100 K. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SIR92 and model refined using CRYSTALS. The C and N atoms of the amine molecules were modeled isotropically. In 2 some of the dipyridyl ligands were found to be disordered over two crystallographically inequivalent positions, and therefore their site occupancies refined. The data were treated with SQUEEZE to correct the effect of the disordered organic cations

Lattice parameters at 100 K: a = 37.055(3) Å, b = 19.3093(13) Å, c = 18.5411(12) Å, space group Pcca

cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of a two-dimensional [Ga10S16(NC7H9)(N2C12H10)3/2]2- layer parallel to the (135) plane; (b) framework topology of 2, each node represents a supertetrahedral cluster; (c) view of 2 along [100].

metadata.title: Gallium−Sulfide Supertetrahedral Clusters as Building Blocks of Covalent Organic−Inorganic Networks
